title: WHL Notebook: Decision day for WHL teams with too many 20-year-olds
text:
’s overage deadline hits this morning. 
’t count until he returns. 
’s no word whether McGauley is on the 30-day injury list, but he has already missed more than two weeks and remains week-to-week on the WHL injury report. 
’t have to make a decision any time soon with two 20-year-olds on the injury list. 
’s a breakdown of the overagers in the league, based on online team rosters and the league’s injury report on Tuesday evening. 
Calgary (3) 
Edmonton (3) 
Everett (4) 
Kamloops (4) 
Kelowna (4)

s WHL injury report. 
HEADED WEST: Former Wheat Kings forward Dario Winkler has been claimed by the Everett Silvertips. The 18-year-old Austrian got caught up in the numbers game when the Wheat Kings settled on Rihards Bukarts and Ivan Provorov as their two imports. 
WEEKLY AWARDS: Moose Jaw Warriors forward Brayden Point was named the WHLs top player for the week ending Oct. 11. He had nine points in three games. 
For the second week in a row, Coleman Vollrath was the WHLs nominee for CHL goalie of the week, and this time he claimed the national award. He had a 3-1 record with a goals-against average of 1.00 and a save percentage of .960. 
KAMLOOPS CHANGES: Blazers general manager Craig Bonner stepped down on Tuesday to scout for the Dallas Stars, but the job wasnt open long. Stu MacGregor, who was the team’s GM from 1995 to 1998, was named general manager again after 17 years of scouting in the NHL. Bonner was in his eighth season in the job when he left. 
DEFENDER RETURNS: The Prince Albert Raiders received some good news on Tuesday when 18-year-old defenceman Brendan Guhle was returned by the Buffalo Sabres. Guhle, a second round NHL draft pick who has signed an entry level contract, was injured in the NHL preseason on a hit by Toronto Maple Leafs defenceman Dion Phaneuf. He has since been cleared to play. Republished from the Brandon Sun print edition October 14, 2015
